questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is iatrogenic due to administration of 
corticosteroids.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following causes ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Cushing’s disease causes ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. It occurs due to an 
ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Cushing’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Cushing’s disease, and all other causes of Cushing's syndrome, can result in a 
hypercoagulable state. This is due to an increase in procoagulant factors and inhibition of 
fibrinolysis. Cushing's disease is a form of Cushing's syndrome caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor. 
The high ACTH levels stimulate melanocytes and cause skin hyperpigmentation. This is especially 
seen over friction-prone areas like knuckles and elbows. The majority of patients with Cushing's syndrome have psychiatric symptoms such as: • Anxiety, • Depression, and • Frank psychosis Mineralocorticoid action of cortisol may lead to diastolic hypertension, hypokalemia, and edema.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent 
menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her 
face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg 
and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations 
should you advise this patient?

options.c: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are 
suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight 
serum cortisol measurement. Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease. Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a 
diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar 
features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

questions.question:
Question 7: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having 
Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with 
Cushing's syndrome. Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent 
causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome. 148

questions.question:
Question 8: In patients with which of the following conditions would you expect to see the highest basal 
ACTH level?
questions.explanation:
Basal plasma ACTH levels are highest in ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. Plasma ACTH > 15pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome due to pituitary 
or ectopic sources. Basal ACTH in pituitary adenoma can be normal or elevated, whereas in an 
ectopic source the ACTH production is very high. This occurs because a pituitary adenoma retains 
some sensitivity to the negative feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol, but ectopic tumors 
remain unaffected. Plasma ACTH < 5pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome that can be 
caused by an adrenal adenoma or exogenous administration of glucocorticoids.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with suspected Cushing's syndrome is found to have elevated ACTH levels. What is 
the investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
An elevated ACTH level is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. The investigation 
of choice for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome is MRI brain, to look for the presence of 
a pituitary tumour. If the MRI brain shows a mass it is suggestive of a pituitary mass of >6 mm in size. However, if 
the MRI brain does not show a mass it suggests a pituitary tumor of <6mm in size or an ectopic 
ACTH source. Note: High-dose dexamethasone suppression test and CRH stimulation test are employed to 
differentiate pituitary from ectopic ACTH syndrome. A definitive cause can be established only by 
imaging techniques like MRI for pituitary tumors, CT scan of the chest and abdomen for ectopic 
ACTH sites. Hence MRI is considered the investigation of choice.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. As MRI of 
the pituitary was normal and further testing was unequivocal, she was scheduled for inferior 
petrosal sinus sampling. It revealed a baseline petrosal:peripheral ACTH ratio > 2. What is 
the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cushing’s syndrome with petrosal: peripheral ACTH ratio > 2 at baseline confirms the 
presence of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The treatment of choice is transsphenoidal 
pituitary surgery. Radiotherapy is used in case of recurrence of tumors. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is performed to differentiate pituitary and ectopic sources of 
ACTH when initial imaging and testing are inconclusive.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following would not be used to treat patients with Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Mitomycin is not used in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome. The drugs used in its management 
include: • Metyrapone • Ketoconazole • Aminoglutethimide • Trilostane • Cyproheptadine • Mitotane – Mainly in adrenal carcinoma • Etomidate – Severe cortisol excess

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following complications is associated with bilateral adrenalectomy?
questions.explanation:
Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a 
procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary 
adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible. The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases 
CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the 
original pituitary tumor or the formation of a new one. Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of: • Hyperpigmentation • Excessive ACTH secretion • Corticotroph adenoma Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular 
intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The 
primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid 
replacement, as they do not produce cortisol. The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need 
for bilateral adrenalectomy these days. Option A: Sheehan’s syndrome refers to postpartum hypopituitarism that is caused by ischemic 
necrosis of the anterior pituitary as a result of severe postpartum hemorrhage. Option B: Addison's disease occurs due to autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands. Option C: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome refers to adrenal apoplexy that is caused by 
fulminant meningococcemia.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a cause of pseudo-Cushing's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Malignancy does not cause pseudo-Cushing's syndrome. It may cause ectopic ACTH production, 
leading to true Cushing’s syndrome. Pseudo-Cushing’s syndrome refers to functional hypercortisolism caused by chronic activation of 
the HPA axis. It presents with clinical and biochemical features similar to Cushing’s syndrome, 
making it difficult to differentiate between them. It may occur secondary to the following 
conditions: • Severe major depressive disorder • Polycystic ovarian syndrome • Insulin-resistant obesity • Obstructive sleep apnea • Chronic alcoholism 152
